pageContext.claim: “When I campaigned, they hadn't had rate increases, pay increases for 20 years, 21 years. They were working three jobs and two jobs, and making less money than they made 20 years ago.”
pageContext.analysis: Bureau of Labor Statistics data show that the percentage of people working two jobs has actually declined since the Great Recession — and been relatively steady at around 5 percent since 2010. Going back 20 years, the percentage was only about six percent. Adjusted for inflation, the purchasing power of paychecks have barely budged over the past 40 years, though the CBO found wages grew for all income groups, from top to bottom, during the period. The rate of increase, however, was most dramatic for the top 1 percent, while everyone else saw relatively modest increases.
